name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Sacred groves and sand dunes need to be protected and restored.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: The regeneration is very less in the two observation plots.

name: Site/area protection
note: Increasing the area of this species' range circumscribed by protected areas is a priority, as is ensuring existing protected areas are sufficiently resourced to safeguard this species (and others) from habitat loss and hunting.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Choudhury (2009) recommended that awareness campaigns amongst rural communities are carried out.

name: Site/area protection
note: Enforcing protection in the Great Nicobar Biosphere Reserve will be important to safeguarding its future.

name: Site/area protection
note: Develop a community-governed protected area on Katchall (K. Sivakumar in litt. 2012).

name: Site/area protection
note: The principal action needed is the (effective) protection of remaining lowland blocks of forest, especially in Cambodia, Lao PDR and Myanmar, all of which likely host a significant proportion of the global population of this species. Stop selective logging in mature stands of sal Shorea robusta in Himalayan foothills (Kumar and Shahabuddin 2012).

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: The principal action needed is the (effective) protection of remaining lowland blocks of forest, especially in Cambodia, Lao PDR and Myanmar, all of which likely host a significant proportion of the global population of this species.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Increase forest connectivity throughout its range.

name: Scale unspecified
note: None

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Yang et al. 2011, Anon. 2015), and work with governments along the East Asian – Australasian Flyway to prevent destruction of key migratory staging sites (Anon. 2015). Implement protection of Australian non-breeding habitats, as well as protecting stopover sites.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Raise awareness of the species.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect remaining intertidal habitats across the species's range (including the Yellow Sea) to prevent further habitat loss and degradation (Yang et al. 2011, Anon. 2015), and work with governments along the East Asian – Australasian Flyway to prevent destruction of key migratory staging sites (Anon. 2015).

name: Policies and regulations
note: Incorporate requirements for this species and others into coastal planning (Anon. 2015).

name: Site/area management
note: Manage important sites to reduce the impact of disturbance (Anon. 2015).

name: Linked enterprises & livelihood alternatives
note: Involve Indigenous owners in management of local land.

name: Species recovery
note: Depending on the outcome of these surveys, a conservation action plan that prioritises site and population protections will be key.

name: Harvest management
note: The harvest of the species must be managed to sustainable levels.

name: Site/area protection
note: Identifying, protecting, and safeguarding key sites from future development is crucial for the long-term stability of the species. Any established protected areas need to coincide with effective management and abundant regional support, and the focus should be on creating a network of key sites.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Enhance communication, education, and public awareness of the values of migratory waterbirds.

name: Scale unspecified
note: Compliance and enforcement may be necessary to control hunting of the species, as will no-hunting laws in local communities.

name: Linked enterprises & livelihood alternatives
note: The focus for controlling hunting should be on alternative livelihoods rather than enforcement/compliance measures, as this is more likely to produce mutually beneficial outcomes.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Viable methods need to be developed for controlling smooth cordgrass throughout China and the Korean peninsula to restore ecosystem viability and prevent further intertidal habitat loss.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Research to determine and establish restoration projects in key areas is vital, as is continuing and preserving current restoration projects.

name: Site/area protection
note: Extend, upgrade and link existing protected areas, and establish new ones, in order to conserve remaining tracts of natural grassland.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Promote widespread conservation awareness initiatives focusing on sustainable management of grassland to maximise both thatch productivity for local people and available habitat for threatened grassland birds.

name: Site/area management
note: Control livestock grazing in protected areas and regulate grassland burning (A. Choudhury in litt. 2016) to reduce rates of tall grassland loss and degradation.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Promote regeneration of suitable grassland habitats wherever possible.

name: Species recovery
note: Create conservation blue-prints/plans for species throughout its range, particularly in Myanmar, Cambodia and Indonesia, where the only remaining viable populations persist.

name: Reintroduction
note: Reintroduce the species in areas where threats are controlled, if deemed viable and feasible.

name: Captive breeding/artificial propagation
note: Establish captive breeding program/s if deemed necessary and feasible.

name: Site/area protection
note: Establish areas of suitable habitat in non-protected forests as Protected Areas or OECMs.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Engage local communities to strengthen the protection of existing protected areas. Community engagement to discourage accidental and intentional offtake of the species, coupled with awareness-raising campaigns to educate local people how harmful practices can be carried out in less damaging ways.

name: National level
note: Strengthen existing legislation and improve enforcement to prevent hunting and the poaching of eggs.

name: National level
note: Existing Protected Areas should be subject to increased enforcement and compliance measures.

name: Site/area management
note: Existing habitat should be restored via de-siltation and weeding of forest wetlands. Take action to avoid contamination via oil drilling in these areas.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Control weeds in existing habitat.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Existing habitat should be restored via de-siltation and weeding of forest wetlands. Create new habitat via reforestation efforts and wetland creation.

name: Site/area protection
note: The most urgent conservation action needed for this species is the protection of much (if not ideally all) suitable habitat within its range (Praveen J and Nameer 2012); currently, only the Aralam Wildlife Sanctuary is protected, in which recent surveys found it at lower densities than elsewhere (Aparnadevi and Vinayan 2013).

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: The most urgent conservation action needed for this species is the protection of much (if not ideally all) suitable habitat within its range (Praveen J and Nameer 2012); currently, only the Aralam Wildlife Sanctuary is protected, in which recent surveys found it at lower densities than elsewhere (Aparnadevi and Vinayan 2013).

name: Site/area protection
note: Protect areas of suitable habitat.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Protect areas of suitable habitat.

name: Site/area protection
note: Continue to lobby for the protection of suitable grasslands within its range, either as national parks or community reserves, and ensure they are appropriately managed for this and other marshland species.

name: Awareness & communications
note: More broadly, promote widespread conservation awareness initiatives focusing on sustainable management of grassland to maximise both thatch productivity for local people and available habitat for threatened grassland bird species.

name: Site/area management
note: Continue to lobby for the protection of suitable grasslands within its range, either as national parks or community reserves, and ensure they are appropriately managed for this and other marshland species.

name: Habitat & natural process restoration
note: Continue to lobby for the protection of suitable grasslands within its range, either as national parks or community reserves, and ensure they are appropriately managed for this and other marshland species.

name: Site/area protection
note: Extend, upgrade and link where possible existing protected areas, and establish new ones, in order to adequately conserve remaining tracts of grassland.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Promote widespread conservation awareness initiatives focusing on grassland regeneration and sustainable management of grassland to maximise both thatch productivity for local people and available habitat for threatened grassland birds.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: Control livestock grazing in protected areas to reduce rates of tall grassland loss and degradation. Control invasive plant species.

name: Site/area management
note: Implement flood control measures in and around national parks.

name: Site/area protection
note: Ensure that habitats within the Kameng protected area remain safe by opposing further road developments.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: In the East Asian-Australasian Flyway, the main action needed for this is the amelioration of threats on its migration. China needs to implement its plan to eliminate 90+% of Spartina cordgrass to prevent further loss of feeding habitat (much has already been lost to land reclamation; IUCN 2023). The discharge of toxic pollutants into coastal wetlands (especially where there are large shorebird congregations) needs to be controlled. Further degradation of mudflats needs to be stopped, including monitoring and preventing detrimental release of riverine sediments and responsible planning of offshore windfarms.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: China needs to implement its plan to eliminate 90+% of Spartina cordgrass to prevent further loss of feeding habitat (much has already been lost to land reclamation; IUCN 2023).

name: Policies and regulations
note: Further degradation of mudflats needs to be stopped, including monitoring and preventing detrimental release of riverine sediments and responsible planning of offshore windfarms. Tools are available, such as AviStep (https://avistep.birdlife.org/) to ensure sustainable building of renewable energy infrastructure.

name: Site/area management
note: In the East Asian-Australasian Flyway, the main action needed for this is the amelioration of threats on its migration. China needs to implement its plan to eliminate 90+% of Spartina cordgrass to prevent further loss of feeding habitat (much has already been lost to land reclamation; IUCN 2023). The discharge of toxic pollutants into coastal wetlands (especially where there are large shorebird congregations) needs to be controlled. Further degradation of mudflats needs to be stopped, including monitoring and preventing detrimental release of riverine sediments and responsible planning of offshore windfarms.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Increase regional and local awareness about the uniqueness of this species as well as to promote the value of its habitat which is usually regarded of least interest due to its semiarid condition with low sparse vegetation.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: To avoid habitat alteration activities including plantation of other species for greening the area which is a unique habitat. Avoid the construction of water harvesting structures.

name: Invasive/problematic species control
note: The most problematic invasive alien species in the area is Prosopis juliflora. It is needed to undertake preventive measures to control the invasion of such species.

name: Site/area protection
note: Create microreserves to protect all the known subpopulations.

name: Species recovery
note: Implement priority actions identified in the Buff-breasted Sandpiper Conservation plan and the 2015 symposium.

name: Site/area protection
note: Conserve key breeding, staging and wintering sites.

name: Site/area management
note: Implement conservation at key wintering locations to ensure suitable habitat conditions are available and enhanced.

name: Harvest management
note: Consideration of harvesting individuals for ex situ captive breeding

name: Trade management
note: No current legal trade in wild Banteng

name: Species recovery
note: Consideration and planning in situ management of genetic stock. Ex situ management (captive-breeding) of genetic stock Review of facilities and expertise enabling the development of breeding and reintroduction programmes

name: Awareness & communications
note: Local level education programmes and community-outreach programmes to protect Banteng or form collaborations with existing NGOs conducting species educational programmes

name: National level
note: Inclusion into CITES to prevent international trade

name: Sub-national level
note: Upgrade Banteng status to totally protected, removing all hunting licenses for extant populations

name: National level
note: Review of current legislation and enforcement of penalties specific to Banteng including on snares

name: Sub-national level
note: Review of current legislation and enforcement of penalties specific to Banteng including on snares

name: Site/area management
note:
Forest and grassland management specific to the longevity of Banteng
Patrols and enforcement within Banteng habitat
Artificial mineral licks to supplement populations in Sabah and Thailand

name: Site/area protection
note: In Europe (particularly Finland), there is an urgent need to safeguard peatland breeding grounds from forestry.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: In Europe (particularly Finland), there is an urgent need to safeguard peatland breeding grounds from forestry.

name: Site/area management
note: China needs to implement its plan to eliminate 90+% of Spartina cordgrass to prevent further loss of feeding habitat (much has already been lost to land reclamation; IUCN 2023). The discharge of toxic pollutants into coastal wetlands (especially where there are large shorebird congregations) needs to be controlled. Further degradation of mudflats needs to be stopped, including monitoring and preventing detrimental release of riverine sediments and responsible planning of offshore windfarms.

name: Awareness & communications
note: Carry out environmental education programmes among the local population.

name: Resource & habitat protection
note: Effectively protect significant areas of suitable habitat at key sites, in both strictly protected areas and multiple use areas.

name: International level
note: Improve the enforcement of laws restricting the trade of the species. Improve the monitoring of the species being traded internationally, particularly via local boats.

name: National level
note: Improve the enforcement of national laws that restrict the trade of the species.

name: Trade management
note: Find more effective ways to monitor and restrict the illegal trade of the species.

name: Site/area protection
note: Formally protect key feeding and breeding sites.
